newsitem.title: INDONESIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - May 15.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indonesian newspapers - May 15.

text.p: The following are the leading stories in the Indonesian press on May 15. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
The ruling Golkar party has denied having any connection with a plan by an affiliated Moslem group to distribute free food to poor people on election day.
Indonesia's richest man Liem Sie Liong, 81, said he did not know from where his wealth had come from but he had worked hard all his life since emigrating from China as a young man of 21 years.

Six died in campaign-related traffic accidents during illegal street rallies held by supporters of the United Development Party (PPP) in the capital on Wednesay and some small clashes were reported between security forces and rowdy supporters as well as between rival political groups.

Indonesian President Suharto has appealed to Indonesia's minority ethnic groups to strengthen nationalism and work together with the rest of the nation to face the challenges of the 21st century. He said all Indonesians citizens were equal before the law.

The Capital Market Supervisory Body (Bapepam) has fined two securities companies, their directors and executives of the Jakarta Stock Exchange for their part in irregular share trading activities involving Bank Pikko.
